editionStmt.edition: Digital edition according to TEI P5

availability.licence: This document is published under the Creative Commons licence Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0).

msDesc.head: Astronomical Collection Winchester s. XI1 (with additions from s. XI2 ) Digital facsimile at Wren Digital Library

supportDesc.foliation: One unpaginated folio. The rest paginated 1-217 in brownish ink in the upper right corner of every recto. Two foliation in pencil 1-7 and 1-111, both now crossed-over.

collation.p: Bishop suggested that the first quire was originally of eight leaves with hairside outside, having the first two leaves probably left blank. By the bindning with the Calendar (quire II-III) the outer bifolium of the first quire was detached, turned inside out and folded around the second quire, and the blank last folio cut out. This would explain why the astronomical sections continues also on pages 11 and 12, which are part of the second quire with the calendar, and why they are not rulled in the same manner the rest of the quire. It will also account for the fact that the first quire opens with flesh-side outside.

layoutDesc.layout: Pp.1-212 written in one column in 25 lines (with the exception of the tables) ruled in dry point.
Cicero's Aratea on pp. written in two columns.

handDesc.handNote: The astronomical part (pp. 1-14 and 39-216) mainly written by one hand.

binding.p: Early-modern binding in braun leather and an embossed coat of arms of George Willmer (1582–1626) in gold on the front cover with a proverb expertus credo.

origin.p: The astronomical section. Furthermore on p.165 Robinson identified the hand as that ofAelsinus, a monk of Hyde Abbey (New Minster), who wrote London, BL, Cotton Titus D. XXXVI fols. 68-75 and Stowe 994 which is the "Liber Vitae" of Hyde Abbey.

The Calendar section on pp. 13-26 was written in New Minster near Winchester most probably in mid 1030s. On p.17 for the 27th March is noted Resurrectio christi, which was true for the year 1036. Robinson also observed a cross in hard point for the year 1036 in the Paschal tables on pp. 32-5. Usually such makring points the following Easter and in this case would suggest that pp. 13-26 were written between Easter 1035 and Easter 1036.

provenance.p: The MS was transferred from Hyde Abbey to St. Augustine's Abbey at Canterbury at the end of the 11th century. The astronomical parts are recorded in the Canterbury St. Augustine's catalogue under no. 1157. At the same time the Calendar also passed into the ownership of St. Augustine's Canterbury as is visible by few but notable 11th-century additions such as the local for Canterbury feasts of Saints Mildred on 13th July (p.21) and Eanswitha on 31th August (p.22).

The two MS parts were united in their present form in the 11th c. Bishop points to additions (filling text) on the first folio of the fourth quire (p. 37-38) which was probably initially left blank as the opening of a separate booklet. The unfinished table of the cyclus decemnovennalis on the first unpaginated page is written by an 11th c. hand.

listBibl.head: Selected Bibliography:
listBibl.bibl: T. A. M. Bishop. “Notes on Cambridge Manuscripts. Part II.” Transactions of the Cambridge Bibliographical Society 2, no. 2 (1955): 185–99.

Gneuss, H. Handlist of Anglo-Saxon Manuscripts: a List of Manuscripts and Manuscript Fragments Written or Owned in England up to 1100, Medieval and Renaissance Studies 241 (Tempe, AZ, 2001), no. 186 [MS in two parts, one s. xi in., the other s. xi1 (1035/6); both parts origin New Minster, Winchester, provenance St Augustine's Canterbury by s. xi ex.]

Morgan, N. and Panayotova, S. (eds.) with the assistance of Rebecca Rushforth. Illuminated Manuscripts in Cambridge : A Catalogue of Western Book Illumination in the Fitzwilliam Museum and the Cambridge Colleges. Part 4, The British Isles, 2 vols. (London, 2013), vol 1. no. 34.
Ker, Neil. R. Medieval libraries of Great Britain: a list of surviving books. London: Offices of the Royal Historical Society, 1941.
McGurk, P. "The Astronomical Section," in An Eleventh-Century Anglo-Saxon Illustrated Miscellany, ed. P. McGurk, Early Engilsh Manuscripts in Facsimile 21 (Copenhagen, 1983), 67-70.
Wormald, F.English Drawings in the Tenth and Eleventh Centuries. London: , 1952, p. 64.
Keynes, S. Anglo-Saxon manuscripts: and other items of related interest in the library of Trinity College, Cambridge. Binghamton, N.J.: Cemers, 1992.
Robinson, P. Catalogue of dated and datable manuscripts c. 737 - 1600 in Cambridge libraries. Cambridge: Brewer, 1988.
Ker, Neil R. Catalogue of manuscripts containing Anglo-Saxon. Oxford: Clarendon, 1957.

Morgan, N. J. and Panayotova, S. (eds.). Illuminated manuscripts in Cambridge: a catalogue of western book illumination in the Fitzwilliam Museum and the the Cambridge colleges. Part 4, The British Isles. Vol. 1: Insular and Anglo-Saxon manuscripts c. 700 - c. 1100. London: Miller, 2013.

msItem.incipit:
Primus annus
Secundus annus
msItem.note: unfinished list written on a previously blank page. Early-modern titleTract. de Astrologia.
Early-modern table of content.Ex libris of Trinity College.

msItem.title: Excerptum de astronomia
msItem.rubric: In nomine domini incipit inuolutio sperae
msItem.incipit: Duo sunt extremi uertices mundi quos appelant polos
msItem.explicit: effusionem urnae aquarii quae ad ipsum usque decurrit accipiens.

msItem.author: Abbo of Fleury
msItem.title: Sententia Abbonis de differentia circuli
msItem.rubric: Sententia Abbonis de differentia circuli et sperae
msItem.incipit: Studiosis astrologiae primo sciendum est per geometricam quid distat inter circulum et speram
msItem.explicit: Si uero nota est aliquis planetarum est.
msItem.decoNote: P. 6 diagram on the planetary evagation through the zodiacal band with rubricFigura ad superiora dicta utilis.
msItem.bibl: Eastwood, Bruce Stansfield. “Astronomy in Christian Latin Europe c.500-c.1150.”Journal for the History of Astronomy 28 (1997): 235–58 (esp. 251-52).

msItem.author: Abbo of Fleury
msItem.title: Untitled
msItem.incipit: Denique luna totius zodiaci signa puncta partes studiooso lectori manifestabit
msItem.explicit: in piscibus martem esse modo credimus. Somiliter de reliquis.
msItem.decoNote: P. 8 diagram of waxing and wanning moon.

msItem.author: Abbo of Fleury
msItem.title: De duplici signorum ortu uel occasu
msItem.rubric: Abbo de duplici signorum ortu uel occasu
msItem.incipit: De duplici ortu signorum dubitantes aliquando has ratione conueni
msItem.explicit: matutino exortu hiemalem horrorem, vespertino vernalem adducunt temperiem.

msItem.author: Abbo of Fleury
msItem.title: De quinque circulis mundi
msItem.incipit: Idem de quinque circulis mundi. Quinque tenent caelum zonae quarum una corusco
msItem.explicit: unde etiam fit ut duae zonae frigidissimae sint, ad quas sol numquam accedit.

msItem.note: Computistical table for finding the moon within the zodiac. Below list of epacts.
Diagram for the horologium - six circles grouping the months in pairsIanuarius et december hora III et IX pedes XVII, hora VI pedes XI etc.
Calendrical texts (on thequatuor ieiunia legitima; the date of the nonas, idus and the number of days in a month throughout the year; computistical table).

msItem.incipit: Principium iani sancit tropicus capricornus
msItem.note: Entries for religious feasts, astronomical-calendrical phaenomena (Sol intrat pisces, Orion et gladius eius incipiunt abscondi etc.); interestingly on 27th March is noted Resurrectio christi, which was true for the year 1036; slightly later added also unfavourable days (dies mala).

Computus tables linked to the columns of key letters in the calendar: pp. 27-28 Litterae punctatae table; p. 29 table for the monthly lunar epacts; p. 30 Pagina regulares; p. 31 Table with the lunar letters AEIOV.

msItem.incipit: De LXXma. Post XVI KL Febr ubi lunam X inueneris ibi fac terminum setuagessimae.
msItem.explicit: Si uis scire quot concurrentes sint omni anno, scias quota feria sit IX KL apr. tot concurrentes erunt in illo anno procerto.

msItem.title: De diebus egyptiaci
msItem.incipit: KL Ian. Iani prima dies et septima fine timetur
msItem.explicit: KL Dec. Dat duodena cohors septem inde dexemque decembri.
msItem.note: later addition from XIex to the first folio of the following quire (initially left blank)
A computistical table (?) with a zodiacal diagram (later addition from XIex.

msItem.incipit: Et si te studio grammaticae artis inductum
msItem.explicit: ad propositum ueniemus et initium rerum demonstrabimus.

msItem.incipit: Mundus appellatur is qui constat ex sole et luna et terra et omnibus stellis
msItem.explicit: Nos autem omnium corpoprum deformationem dicere instituimus.

msItem.incipit: Igitur incipiemus a polo boreo protinus dicere
msItem.decoNote: Space left for illustration (exeptions on p. 99 row pendrawing of a human figure, p. 102 Equus; p. 104 Taurus, possibly taken from an inhabited initial; p. 109 Pisces; p. 114 Piscis australis).

msItem.incipit: Quae ad figurationem siderum pertinent adhunc finem
msItem.explicit: Cum sol ab aestiuo circulo descendens CCCtos LXta V dies suo cursu transigit.

msItem.author: Martianus Capella
msItem.title: De nuptiis(Book 8.De astronomia
msItem.rubric: Martiani Minei Felicis Capellae afri cartaginensis de astrologia liber incipit in nomine domini nostri ihesu christi.
msItem.incipit: Quaedum geruntur et deorum sacer senatus illos numerorum concinentium
msItem.explicit: aut in profundum deprimit aut in latitudinem declinare aut retrogradari facit.
msItem.note: many interlinear glosses; p. 165 was erased and rewritten by a different hand, which Bishop identified in two other Hyde manuscripts - London, BL, Add. Ms. 3489 (ff. 158-160) and Stowe Ms. 944 (41r and 59r).

msItem.author: Helperic
msItem.title: Expositio computi
msItem.incipit: Cum quibusdam fratribus nostris adolescentulis quaedam
msItem.explicit: alfabeti caracteribus inducti, illa deinceps facilius assequantur.
msItem.finalRubric: Finit excerptio uel expositio compoti heririci(corrected to helperici) uiri doctissimi.

msItem.author: Abbo of Fleury
msItem.title: Excerptio Abbonis ex Igino de figuratione signorum
msItem.rubric: Incipit excerptio abbonis ex igino de figuratione signorum
msItem.incipit: Denique ut dicit plinius inter omnia sunt LXXII signa
msItem.explicit: cuius et gubernaculum et rectam puppim secans ad octauam partem cancri redit.

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.incipit: Domine deus omnipotens sancta trinitas
msItem.explicit: aliis ministrare ualeamus. per eundem dominum.

msItem.title: On the creation of the luminaries according to the bible
msItem.incipit: Sancta scriptura nobis a deo per beatum moysen tradita
msItem.explicit: et luminare minus ut preesset nocti.

msItem.title: De duodecim signis
msItem.rubric: De XII signis sed primum de ariete
msItem.incipit: Regionem duodecimam caeli in quam sol cursum suum dirigit
msItem.explicit: sed christus dominus saluator mundi euertit.

msItem.author: Cicero
msItem.title: Aratea
msItem.incipit: Quinque solent stellae simili ratione notari
msItem.explicit: Hanc autem totam properant depellere pisces.
